Arbitrary beam control using passive lossless metasurfaces enabled by orthogonally-polarized custom surface waves

Do-Hoon Kwon dhkwon@umass.edu Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Massachusetts Amherst, Amherst, Massachusetts 01003, USA â€ƒâ€ƒ Sergei A. Tretyakov Department of Electronics and Nanoengineering, Aalto University, P.O. Box 15500, 00076 Aalto, Finland
Abstract

For passive, lossless impenetrable metasurfaces, a design technique for arbitrary beam control of receiving, guiding, and launching is presented. Arbitrary control is enabled by a custom surface wave in an orthogonal polarization such that its addition to the incident (input) and the desired scattered (output) fields is supported by a reactive surface impedance everywhere on the reflecting surface. Such a custom surface wave (SW) takes the form of an evanescent wave propagating along the surface with a spatially varying envelope. A growing SW appears when an illuminating beam is received. The SW amplitude stays constant when power is guided along the surface. The amplitude diminishes as a propagating wave (PW) is launched from the surface as a leaky wave. The resulting reactive tensor impedance profile may be realized as an array of anisotropic metallic resonators printed on a grounded dielectric substrate. Illustrative design examples of a Gaussian beam translator-reflector, a probe-fed beam launcher, and a near-field focusing lens are provided.

I Introduction

Comprising an electrically thin layer of subwavelength resonatorsÂ HollowayÂ etÂ al. (2012), metasurfaces are capable of tailoring the characteristics of propagating and evanescent waves with a significantly reduced loss compared with traditional volumetric metamaterials. In particular, gradient metasurfaces, those with spatially varying surface parameters, have received increased attention in recent years. By imparting a linearly gradient discontinuity on a reflection or transmission phase, the incident wave can be deflected anomalously upon reflection or transmission. Since a recent formalization of the generalized laws of reflection and refractionÂ YuÂ etÂ al. (2011), a wide variety of novel metasurface applications have been proposed and demonstrated. Using penetrable metasurfaces, anomalous refraction has been demonstrated from microwave to optical regimesÂ YuÂ etÂ al. (2011); AietaÂ etÂ al. (2012); PfeifferÂ andÂ Grbic (2013); WongÂ etÂ al. (2015); AsadchyÂ etÂ al. (2015). Introducing a proper nonlinear phase distribution leads to lensesÂ MonticoneÂ etÂ al. (2013); LinÂ etÂ al. (2014); WangÂ etÂ al. (2015); KhorasaninejadÂ etÂ al. (2016). Holograms are designed by locally controlling the transmission amplitude and/or phaseÂ NiÂ etÂ al. (2013); HuangÂ etÂ al. (2013). A careful geometrical arrangement of transmission blocks having different transmission phases can create optical vortex beamsÂ YuÂ etÂ al. (2011); GenevetÂ etÂ al. (2012); KarimiÂ etÂ al. (2014); ShalaevÂ etÂ al. (2015); ChongÂ etÂ al. (2015).

A variety of novel functionalities have also been demonstrated in the reflection mode or for impenetrable metasurfaces. Anomalous reflection described by the generalized Snellâ€™s law has been in use for reflectarray designs in the antenna engineering communityÂ HuangÂ andÂ Encinar (2008). Reflection-mode lensesÂ PorsÂ etÂ al. (2013); AsadchyÂ etÂ al. (2015), hologramsÂ ZhengÂ etÂ al. (2015); WenÂ etÂ al. (2015), and optical vortex generatorÂ YangÂ etÂ al. (2014); YuÂ etÂ al. (2016) have been reported. In SunÂ etÂ al. (2012a), conversion from a plane wave into an SW was cast as a special case of anomalous reflection, wherein the reflected wave vector enters the evanescent (invisible) spectral range. This work has spurred a strong interest in the conversion process and efficiency between propagating and evanescent wavesÂ SunÂ etÂ al. (2012b); WangÂ etÂ al. (2012); PorsÂ etÂ al. (2014); FanÂ etÂ al. (2016), either in the form of surface plasmon polariton waves at optical frequencies or SWs at microwave frequencies. In addition, gradient metasurfaces raised a renewed interest in improving traditional leaky-wave antennas based on arrays of subwavelength printed resonators on a grounded dielectric substrateÂ FongÂ etÂ al. (2010); PatelÂ andÂ Grbic (2011); MinattiÂ etÂ al. (2016a, b). For nonlinear metasurfaces, design of proper phase distributions associated with a judicious choice of nonlinear meta-atom arrangement can manipulate beams such as steering, splitting, focusing, and vortex generation at harmonic frequenciesÂ SegalÂ etÂ al. (2015); WolfÂ etÂ al. (2015); AlmeidaÂ etÂ al. (2016); TymchenkoÂ etÂ al. (2016). If the required grating period allows no more than three propagating Floquet modes, anomalous reflection with nearly unitary efficiency can be realized using a few or even a single inclusion per period, using blazed gratings LoewenÂ etÂ al. (1977) or recent conceptualizations such as meta-gratings Raâ€™diÂ etÂ al. (2017) and agressively discretized metasurfaces WongÂ andÂ Eleftheriades (2017).

Along with the designs and demonstrations of novel wave transformations, their efficiencies started to receive attention. Toward complete wavefront tailoring via a complete 2â€‹Ï€2ğœ‹2\pi transmission phase coverage, the generalized Snellâ€™s laws were demonstrated using cross-polarized light in YuÂ etÂ al. (2011); AietaÂ etÂ al. (2012). It was theoretically revealed that the maximum power coupling efficiency is only 25%Â MonticoneÂ etÂ al. (2013). Utilizing a balanced pair of induced tangential electric and magnetic dipole moments, Huygensâ€™ metasurfacesÂ PfeifferÂ andÂ Grbic (2013); WongÂ etÂ al. (2015) can achieve polarization-preserving full transmission with an arbitrary phase in a complete 2â€‹Ï€2ğœ‹2\pi span. At microwave frequencies, low-loss conductor trances can be arranged to realize the electric and magnetic dipoles. In the optical regime, a careful choice of the dimensions, shape, material, and periodicity for an array of dielectric resonator meta-atoms can bring the electric and magnetic dipole resonances togetherÂ DeckerÂ etÂ al. (2015); CampioneÂ etÂ al. (2015); LiuÂ etÂ al. (2017); ArslanÂ etÂ al. (2017). However, requiring perfect anomalous transmission without reflection using Huygensâ€™ metasurfaces results in globally lossless, but locally active or lossy, surface characterizationsÂ EpsteinÂ andÂ Eleftheriades (2016a). It was found that an Î©Î©\Omega-type bianisotropic metasurface is capable of achieving perfect anomalous refraction without loss or reflectionÂ WongÂ etÂ al. (2016); EpsteinÂ andÂ Eleftheriades (2016b); AsadchyÂ etÂ al. (2016). Similarly for reflective metasurfaces, an anomalous reflector based on the generalized Snellâ€™s lawÂ YuÂ etÂ al. (2011) cannot perfectly reflect an incident plane wave into an anomalous direction, but necessarily entails parasitic reflections into undesired directionsÂ MohammadiÂ EstakhriÂ andÂ AlÃ¹ (2016); AsadchyÂ etÂ al. (2016). Again, requiring that the reflected wave be a single plane wave in the desired anomalous direction results in a strongly dispersive reflecting surface with local active-lossy characteristics. Towards achieving perfect reflection using passive metasurfaces, a reflector design approach based on the leaky-wave antenna principle has been recently reportedÂ DÃ­az-RubioÂ etÂ al. (2017), where a measured reflection power efficiency of 94% has been realized using a printed patch array implementation.

For penetrable metasurfaces, a design recipe for passive, lossless Î©Î©\Omega-type bianisotropic metasurfaces has been introducedÂ EpsteinÂ andÂ Eleftheriades (2016b, c). It was shown that an envisioned wave transformation is supported by a lossless Î©Î©\Omega-type bianisotropic metasurface if power is locally conserved. By introducing auxiliary SWs for equalizing the power on both sides of the surface, designs for a perfect beam split as well as anomalous reflection and refraction have been numerically demonstrated. The same design methodology was applied to a metasurface over a perfect electric conductor surface for perfect anomalous reflectionÂ EpsteinÂ andÂ Eleftheriades (2017). The design philosophy has been recently extended to lossless, impenetrable surfaces characterized by a reactive surface impedance for perfect reflection control of plane wavesÂ KwonÂ andÂ Tretyakov (2017), where SWs of an orthogonal polarization were chosen. Recently, a metasurface design study toward perfect conversion between a plane wave and an SW has been reportedÂ TcvetkovaÂ etÂ al. (2017). In AchouriÂ andÂ Caloz (2016a, b), metasurface designs for SW routing of beams were presented for transmissive metasurfaces. Starting from the generalized sheet transition conditions, spatially-dispersive susceptibilities of the metasurface were specified in terms of the desired field discontinuities. However, such metasurface designs have spatially varying surface parameters with alternately active and lossy properties, posing a challenge for realization.

This paper presents a design technique for passive, lossless impenetrable metasurfaces for perfect beam manipulation. It relies on synthesis of an evanescent auxiliary wave such that the total fields on the metasurface have no real power component through the surface everywhere. It is shown that evanescent waves having a spatially growing and diminishing envelope along the propagation direction can receive and launch PWs, respectively. The exact power profile of this custom SW is determined for a given desired set of illuminating (input) and radiating (output) waves via an efficient numerical optimization procedure. As a natural extension of infinite, periodic metasurface designs for plane wavesÂ KwonÂ andÂ Tretyakov (2017), a treatment of beam manipulation not only provides a design recipe for transforming arbitrary incident waves having a continuum of spectrum, but also demonstrates the versatility of metasurfaces in wave manipulation that is achievable with passive realizations. The design produces an inhomogeneous, anisotropic surface reactance tensor, which may be approximately realized using the standard printed circuit technologies.

II Beam control: perfect receiving, guiding, and launching

FigureÂ 1 illustrates the design problem for an impenetrable metasurface under consideration. In free space, a known beam wave illuminates a planar impenetrable surface in the xâ€‹zğ‘¥ğ‘§xz-plane. Using a passive, lossless metasurface, it desired that the incident beam is first received and converted into an SW, subsequently guided along the surface, before it is launched back into space from a location that is electrically far separated from the receiving point. The power of the desired output wave is the same as that of the incident beam. Furthermore, a surface with reciprocal parameters is desired.

At the heart of the design lies perfect conversion of a PW into an SW and a subsequent transition into lossless guiding along the surface. Launching is a reciprocal process of receiving and a planar structure with a uniform reactive surface impedance can guide an SW without loss. For such a converter based on the generalized Snellâ€™s law, it was found that an SW, once generated, cannot propagate along the gradient metasurface without suffering secondary scattering by the same metasurface back into space. This lowers the conversion efficiency for electrically long convertersÂ QuÂ etÂ al. (2013), defined for the power accepted by a homogeneous guiding metasurface. The conversion efficiency is significantly improved by introducing a meta-coupler at a height over a homogeneous surface that supports a surface waveÂ SunÂ etÂ al. (2016). A drawback of this approach is an increased overall thickness. Nevertheless, the conversion efficiency cannot reach 100% because some of the generated SW fields still undergo secondary scattering by the meta-coupler.

Instead of relying on the generalized reflection law, designing the exact SW tailored to the incident wave can lead to a metasurface design that is capable of perfect PW-to-SW conversion. With respect to the chosen guided direction (the +xğ‘¥+x-axis direction in Fig.Â 1), this custom SW must have a position-dependent amplitude profile such that the amplitude grows over the range of beam illumination due to PW-to-SW conversion, stays constant over the guided range without leakage radiation, then diminishes over the range of beam launch due to SW-to-PW conversion. Over the beam receiving range, the PW is continuously converted into the SW, so there is no abrupt junction between conversion and guiding ranges. The exact profile of the SW is determined such that the PW-to-SW conversion is done in a locally lossless manner, without loss in or power supplied by the metasurface, everywhere on the surface. Once the exact SW is designed, the boundary condition for the impenetrable surface is found for supporting the envisioned total fields as a reactive surface impedance.

In this work, the same polarization is chosen between the input and output beams. For the surface wave, an orthogonal polarization is chosen as in KwonÂ andÂ Tretyakov (2017); TcvetkovaÂ etÂ al. (2017). An orthogonally polarized SW avoids creating an interference power pattern between the PW and SW on the surface, simplifying the SW synthesis significantly. In the following sections, beam controlling metasurfaces in two-dimensional (2-D) configurations with PWs in the TE polarization (with respect to yğ‘¦y) and SWs in the TM polarization are presented.

IV Synthesis of the surface wave

In Fig.Â 1, consider a 2-D configuration where the input and output PW fields are TE-polarized and the SW field is TM-polarized with all the fields invariant along the zğ‘§z-axis. Then, Ezâ€‹(x,y)subscriptğ¸ğ‘§ğ‘¥ğ‘¦E_{z}(x,y) and Hzâ€‹(x,y)subscriptğ»ğ‘§ğ‘¥ğ‘¦H_{z}(x,y) uniquely determine all remaining field components in the xâ€‹yğ‘¥ğ‘¦xy-plane for the TE and TM polarizations, respectively. The electromagnetic uniqueness theorem allows the fields in the half space yâ‰¥0ğ‘¦0y\geq 0, which is bounded by the metasurface and subject to the radiation condition at infinity, to be uniquely determined from those on the metasurface at y=0ğ‘¦0y=0. Furthermore, the planar metasurface geometry makes analysis and design in the spectral domain efficient via Fourier transform. Derivations for field components and the normal component of the Poynting vector are available in AppendicesÂ A and B for TE- and TM-mode fields, respectively.

The metasurface design starts from a complete knowledge of the incident beam and the desired output beam. For a given input beam, we assume that the output PW fields are known from a separate overall function design of the metasurface. In particular, the total output power should be equal to the input power in order to make the overall system lossless. It is stressed that Htâ€‹zâ€‹(x)subscriptğ»ğ‘¡ğ‘§ğ‘¥H_{tz}(x) in (9) is defined on the surface (y=0)ğ‘¦0(y=0) only. At this point, it is instructive to assess the qualitative behavior of the synthesized SW in yâ‰¥0ğ‘¦0y\geq 0. The definition of Htâ€‹zâ€‹(x)subscriptğ»ğ‘¡ğ‘§ğ‘¥H_{tz}(x) with respect to the envelope Aâ€‹(x)ğ´ğ‘¥A(x) in (9) relates their Fourier transforms as

H~tâ€‹zâ€‹(kx)=A~â€‹(kxâˆ’kc).subscript~ğ»ğ‘¡ğ‘§subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¥~ğ´subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘\tilde{H}_{tz}(k_{x})=\tilde{A}(k_{x}-k_{c}). (10)

Since Aâ€‹(x)ğ´ğ‘¥A(x) is a real, non-negative function of xğ‘¥x, A~â€‹(kx)~ğ´subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¥\tilde{A}(k_{x}) has the maximum at kx=0subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¥0k_{x}=0. While a finite spatial support of Aâ€‹(x)ğ´ğ‘¥A(x) makes A~â€‹(kx)~ğ´subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¥\tilde{A}(k_{x}) not completely vanish at large |kx|subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¥|k_{x}|, the effective spectral width of A~â€‹(kx)~ğ´subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¥\tilde{A}(k_{x}) is inversely proportional to the range of non-zero Aâ€‹(x)ğ´ğ‘¥A(x). From (27), the resulting H-field component of the SW in yâ‰¥0ğ‘¦0y\geq 0 is expressed as

Hzâ€‹(x,y)=12â€‹Ï€â€‹âˆ«âˆ’âˆâˆA~â€‹(kxâˆ’kc)â€‹eâˆ’jâ€‹(kxâ€‹x+kyâ€‹y)â€‹ğ‘‘kx.subscriptğ»ğ‘§ğ‘¥ğ‘¦12ğœ‹superscriptsubscript~ğ´subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘superscriptğ‘’ğ‘—subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¥ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¦ğ‘¦differential-dsubscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¥H_{z}(x,y)=\frac{1}{2\pi}\int\limits_{-\infty}^{\infty}\tilde{A}(k_{x}-k_{c})e^{-j(k_{x}x+k_{y}y)}dk_{x}. (11)

It can be seen that the dominant contribution to Hzâ€‹(x,y)subscriptğ»ğ‘§ğ‘¥ğ‘¦H_{z}(x,y) comes from its spectrum at and around kx=kcsubscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘k_{x}=k_{c}. At kx=kcsubscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘k_{x}=k_{c}, the integrand in (11) represents a surface wave bound to the y=0ğ‘¦0y=0 surface with a positive propagation constant of kx=kcsubscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘k_{x}=k_{c} in the xğ‘¥x-direction and an attenuation constant of |ky|=kc2âˆ’k2subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¦superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜ğ‘2superscriptğ‘˜2|k_{y}|=\sqrt{k_{c}^{2}-k^{2}} in the yğ‘¦y-direction. Over the beam reception and launch ranges, the amplitude of the SW grows and diminishes gradually with respect to xğ‘¥x, respectively. In both ranges, the SW propagates in the +xğ‘¥+x-direction and attenuates exponentially in the +yğ‘¦+y-direction. Finally, contributions from all other spectral ranges make the SW exist over the intended, finite range of xğ‘¥x.

Requiring Aâ€‹(x)ğ´ğ‘¥A(x) to be a continuous function, it remains to determine the functions, Aiâ€‹(x)subscriptğ´iğ‘¥A_{\text{i}}(x) and Aoâ€‹(x)subscriptğ´oğ‘¥A_{\text{o}}(x), and the constant A0subscriptğ´0A_{0}. For Aiâ€‹(x)subscriptğ´iğ‘¥A_{\text{i}}(x), we choose a closely spaced set of Ncisubscriptğ‘ciN_{\text{ci}} control points of values Ansubscriptğ´ğ‘›A_{n} at locations x=xcâ€‹nğ‘¥subscriptğ‘¥cğ‘›x=x_{\text{c}n} (n=âˆ’Nci,âˆ’Nci+1,â€¦,âˆ’1)ğ‘›subscriptğ‘cisubscriptğ‘ci1â€¦1(n=-N_{\text{ci}},-N_{\text{ci}}+1,\ldots,-1). Similarly, Ncosubscriptğ‘coN_{\text{co}} number of control points of values Ansubscriptğ´ğ‘›A_{n} at x=xcâ€‹nğ‘¥subscriptğ‘¥cğ‘›x=x_{\text{c}n} (n=1,2,â€¦,Nco)ğ‘›12â€¦subscriptğ‘co(n=1,2,\ldots,N_{\text{co}}) are defined for Aoâ€‹(x)subscriptğ´oğ‘¥A_{\text{o}}(x). The constant level at A0subscriptğ´0A_{0} should make smooth connections to the transition ranges on both sides. A continuous envelope function is then defined using these control points (locations and values) via interpolation. No control points are assigned at the boundary locations of the input and output beam ranges. In Fig.Â 2(b), control points are indicated by red circles. The number and xğ‘¥x-locations of the control points are set appropriately by the designer depending on the allowed complexity of the synthesized SW.

Efficient numerical optimizations can determine the values of Ansubscriptğ´ğ‘›A_{n} (n=âˆ’Nci,â€¦,Nco)ğ‘›subscriptğ‘ciâ€¦subscriptğ‘co(n=-N_{\text{ci}},\ldots,N_{\text{co}}). In this work, a square error function defined by

error=âˆ«âˆ’âˆâˆ|SyTEâ€‹(x)+SyTMâ€‹(x)|2â€‹ğ‘‘xerrorsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘†TEğ‘¦ğ‘¥subscriptsuperscriptğ‘†TMğ‘¦ğ‘¥2differential-dğ‘¥\text{error}=\int\limits_{-\infty}^{\infty}|S^{\text{TE}}_{y}(x)+S^{\text{TM}}_{y}(x)|^{2}dx (12)

is minimized with respect to the Nci+Nco+1subscriptğ‘cisubscriptğ‘co1N_{\text{ci}}+N_{\text{co}}+1 number of control point values. Specifically, a gradient-free optimization method available through the fminsearch function in Matlab has been used for all designs presented in Sec.Â V. After some adjustments to the number and locations of control points, all optimizations converged within a convergence tolerance of 10âˆ’6superscript10610^{-6} relative to the error associated with a null initial guess.

Once the optimized envelope function Aâ€‹(x)ğ´ğ‘¥A(x) is determined, using Htâ€‹zâ€‹(x)subscriptğ»ğ‘¡ğ‘§ğ‘¥H_{tz}(x) from (9) in (28) at y=0ğ‘¦0y=0 finds Etâ€‹xâ€‹(x)subscriptğ¸ğ‘¡ğ‘¥ğ‘¥E_{tx}(x). Together with Etâ€‹zâ€‹(x)subscriptğ¸ğ‘¡ğ‘§ğ‘¥E_{tz}(x) and Htâ€‹xâ€‹(x)subscriptğ»ğ‘¡ğ‘¥ğ‘¥H_{tx}(x) given by the TE-mode fields, they determine the surface reactance tensor that achieves the designed beam control via (3).

Since a spatially varying envelope function is used, the synthesized SW has a continuum of spectrum concentrated around kx=kcsubscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘˜ck_{x}=k_{\text{c}} rather than a discrete spectrum. As a result, some of the spectrum will spill into the visible region (|kx|<k)subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¥ğ‘˜(|k_{x}|<k). This means that satisfaction of (4) for all xğ‘¥x, or equivalently the resulting passive, lossless metasurface, necessarily entails excitation of extra PW components in order to to perform the required beam manipulation. The amount of TM-polarized PW components can be assessed by evaluating the total TM-mode power per unit length in the zğ‘§z-axis direction that escapes the metasurface. This power, denoted PyTMsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘ƒTMğ‘¦P^{\text{TM}}_{y}, is found to have a spectral integral representation given by

PyTM=âˆ«âˆ’âˆâˆSyTMâ€‹(x)â€‹ğ‘‘x=âˆ«âˆ’âˆâˆReâ¡{Î·â€‹ky4â€‹Ï€â€‹kâ€‹|H~tâ€‹zâ€‹(kx)|2}â€‹ğ‘‘kx.subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ƒTMğ‘¦superscriptsubscriptsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘†TMğ‘¦ğ‘¥differential-dğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptReğœ‚subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¦4ğœ‹ğ‘˜superscriptsubscript~ğ»ğ‘¡ğ‘§subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¥2differential-dsubscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¥P^{\text{TM}}_{y}=\int\limits_{-\infty}^{\infty}S^{\text{TM}}_{y}(x)dx=\int\limits_{-\infty}^{\infty}\operatorname{Re}\left\{\frac{\eta k_{y}}{4\pi k}|\tilde{H}_{tz}(k_{x})|^{2}\right\}dk_{x}. (13)

It can be seen that non-zero TM-mode spectrum in the visible region leads to some TM-mode power that is not bound to the metasurface. In principle, this amount of TM-polarized PW components can be reduced to approach zero by increasing kcsubscriptğ‘˜ck_{\text{c}} deep into the invisible range. However, this results in faster spatial variations for the surface impedance tensor elements, making an accurate realization more challenging.

V Design examples

In the following examples, a metasurface design is characterized as a tensor surface impedance ğ™sâ€‹(x)subscriptğ™ğ‘ ğ‘¥\mathbf{Z}_{s}(x), given in terms of the reactance tensor elements in (2). In numerical validations using COMSOL Multiphysics, the impedance boundary condition (1) is enforced at y=0ğ‘¦0y=0.

V.1 Gaussian beam translator-reflector

As a first design example, a translator-reflector for receiving and launching a Gaussian beam (GB) propagating normal to the metasurface is presented. The specific design function is illustrated in Fig.Â 3(a). A 2-D GB propagating in the âˆ’yğ‘¦-y-axis direction illuminates the metasurface with the beam axis aimed at x=âˆ’10â€‹Î»ğ‘¥10ğœ†x=-10\lambda, where Î»ğœ†\lambda is the free-space wavelength. As can be observed in Fig.Â 2(a), SyTEsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘†TEğ‘¦S^{\text{TE}}_{y} and SyTMsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘†TMğ‘¦S^{\text{TM}}_{y} effectively cancel each other. The reactance elements over âˆ’Î»<x<Î»ğœ†ğ‘¥ğœ†-\lambda<x<\lambda are plotted in Fig.Â 3(c). Here, with only a TM-mode SW present, it is noted that Htâ€‹x=0subscriptğ»ğ‘¡ğ‘¥0H_{tx}=0, Etâ€‹z=0subscriptğ¸ğ‘¡ğ‘§0E_{tz}=0, and Reâ¡{Etâ€‹xâ€‹Htâ€‹zâˆ—}=0Resubscriptğ¸ğ‘¡ğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptğ»ğ‘¡ğ‘§0\operatorname{Re}\{E_{tx}H_{tz}^{*}\}=0 in (3). A tensor impedance representation is not appropriate in such a case. In numerical evaluation, (3) may be understood as a limiting case where TE-polarized components approach zero. Still, some numerical artifact is observed in that Xxâ€‹zâ‰ Xzâ€‹xsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘¥ğ‘§subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘§ğ‘¥X_{xz}\neq X_{zx} in Fig.Â 3(c). Since Xzâ€‹x=0subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘§ğ‘¥0X_{zx}=0, no zğ‘§z-directed (TE-polarized) electric field will be generated from an xğ‘¥x-directed electric current. A constant inductive self-reactance at Xxâ€‹x=1.73â€‹Î·subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘¥ğ‘¥1.73ğœ‚X_{xx}=1.73\eta is consistent with a TM-mode surface wave having a propagation constant of kc=2â€‹ksubscriptğ‘˜c2ğ‘˜k_{\text{c}}=2k. In the guided TM-polarized SW range, the tensor surface impedance may well be replaced by an isotropic reactive impedance ğ™s=ğˆtâ€‹jâ€‹Xxâ€‹xsubscriptğ™ğ‘ subscriptğˆğ‘¡ğ‘—subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘¥ğ‘¥\mathbf{Z}_{s}=\mathbf{I}_{t}jX_{xx} (ğˆt=an identity tensor in theÂ xâ€‹y-plane)subscriptğˆğ‘¡an identity tensor in theÂ xy-plane(\mathbf{I}_{t}=\text{an identity tensor in the $xy$-plane}). The scattering characteristics of the metasurface is simulated using COMSOL Multiphysics. Illuminated by the GB the metasurface was designed for, Fig.Â 4(a) plots a snapshot of Ezsubscriptğ¸ğ‘§E_{z} over an area of |x|<20â€‹Î»ğ‘¥20ğœ†|x|<20\lambda, 0<y<16â€‹Î»0ğ‘¦16ğœ†0<y<16\lambda. Non-zero fields are observed tightly bound to the y=0ğ‘¦0y=0 surface. In the inset on the right, a magnified view of the Hzsubscriptğ»ğ‘§H_{z} snapshot is shown over 8â€‹Î»<x<12â€‹Î»8ğœ†ğ‘¥12ğœ†8\lambda<x<12\lambda in the SW-to-PW conversion range. A surface wave with a diminishing amplitude is induced as designed. Over the guided SW range shown in the inset on the left, a TM-polarized SW of a constant amplitude is clearly visible. Over the input beam reception range (a magnified view not shown), the amplitude of the SW gradually grows. In Fig.Â 4(c), the magnitude of the SW field spectrum is plotted with respect to kxsubscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¥k_{x} in both the visible (|kx|â‰¤k)subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¥ğ‘˜(|k_{x}|\leq k) and invisible (|kx|>k)subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¥ğ‘˜(|k_{x}|>k) ranges. Computed using (13), the power associated with the TM-polarized PW component from the visible range is six orders of magnitude below that of the input GB power. Hence, the synthesized TM-polarized SW can be considered completely bound to the reflecting surface.

V.2 Probe current-fed Gaussian beam launcher

A uniform-amplitude SW can be generated by a localized source. Via reciprocity, an SW can be absorbed by a localized lossy material or load impedance. When combined with the PW-to-SW conversion, such a device represents a leaky-wave antenna that transmits or receives a beam wave.

Here, a GB launcher in an oblique angle is designed. For this purpose, the GB translator-reflector of Sec.Â V.1 can be adapted to design an oblique GB launcher excited by an input beam, before the SW feeding mechanism is replaced with a localized current probe. The underlying GB launcher configuration is illustrated in Fig.Â 5(a). The input beam remains unchanged from the translator-reflector design in Sec.Â V.1. The output beam shape remains the same, but it is launched at an angle of Ïˆ0subscriptğœ“0\psi_{0} from the surface normal from x=10â€‹Î»ğ‘¥10ğœ†x=10\lambda. The output beam can be first characterized in a rotated (u,v,w)ğ‘¢ğ‘£ğ‘¤(u,v,w) coordinate system with respect to z=wğ‘§ğ‘¤z=w such that the vğ‘£v-axis is aligned with the output beam axis. Along the uğ‘¢u-axis, the output GB is completely characterized by the wğ‘¤w-component of the electric field

ğ„toâ€‹(u)=ğ„0oâ€‹eâˆ’u2/2â€‹Ïƒ2,ğ„0o=w^â€‹V/m.formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscriptğ„oğ‘¡ğ‘¢subscriptsuperscriptğ„o0superscriptğ‘’superscriptğ‘¢22superscriptğœ2subscriptsuperscriptğ„o0^ğ‘¤V/m\mathbf{E}^{\text{o}}_{t}(u)=\mathbf{E}^{\text{o}}_{0}e^{-u^{2}/2\sigma^{2}},\ \ \mathbf{E}^{\text{o}}_{0}=\hat{w}~{}\text{V/m}. (16)

Then, the output beam fields in the entire uâ€‹vğ‘¢ğ‘£uv-plane can be obtained by applying the relations in AppendixÂ A in the uâ€‹vğ‘¢ğ‘£uv-plane. A special care should be exercised so that the fields in the range v<0ğ‘£0v<0 represent a propagating wave with kv>0subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘£0k_{v}>0. This can be done by taking a complex conjugate of the fields from AppendixÂ A, corresponding to a time-reversal transformation. Fields evaluated along the xğ‘¥x-axis in the uâ€‹vğ‘¢ğ‘£uv-plane can be transformed to the xâ€‹yâ€‹zğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘§xyz system by a proper coordinate rotation, before they can be used for the device design in the xâ€‹yğ‘¥ğ‘¦xy-plane.

For a 30Â° GB launcher (Ïˆ0=30â€‹Â°)subscriptğœ“030Â°(\psi_{0}=30\degree), the xğ‘¥x-range of numerical synthesis of the envelope function was set with xil=âˆ’16â€‹Î»subscriptğ‘¥il16ğœ†x_{\text{il}}=-16\lambda, xiu=âˆ’4â€‹Î»subscriptğ‘¥iu4ğœ†x_{\text{iu}}=-4\lambda, xol=3.75â€‹Î»subscriptğ‘¥ol3.75ğœ†x_{\text{ol}}=3.75\lambda, and xou=16.25â€‹Î»subscriptğ‘¥ou16.25ğœ†x_{\text{ou}}=16.25\lambda. For the output beam, the range was slightly extended to account for the oblique launch angle. In each of xâˆˆ[xil,xiu]ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘¥ilsubscriptğ‘¥iux\in[x_{\text{il}},x_{\text{iu}}] and xâˆˆ[xol,xou]ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘¥olsubscriptğ‘¥oux\in[x_{\text{ol}},x_{\text{ou}}], 15 equally-spaced control points were assigned. Hence, together with A0subscriptğ´0A_{0} assigned to x=0ğ‘¥0x=0, a total of 31 control points were defined for Aâ€‹(x)ğ´ğ‘¥A(x) and they were optimized for the minimum square error (12). The center wavenumber was chosen to be kc=2â€‹ksubscriptğ‘˜c2ğ‘˜k_{\text{c}}=2k. The optimized envelope function together with the control points are plotted in Fig.Â 5(b). The amplitude of the guided SW was found to be A0=16.5â€‹mA/msubscriptğ´016.5mA/mA_{0}=16.5~{}\text{mA/m}, which remains unchanged from the translator-reflector design in Sec.Â V.1 as can be expected. In Fig.Â 5(c), the reactance tensor elements over 9â€‹Î»<x<11â€‹Î»9ğœ†ğ‘¥11ğœ†9\lambda<x<11\lambda in the oblique GB launch range are plotted. They are different from Fig.Â 3(b) and they diverge less frequently with respect to xğ‘¥x. This is due to different phase gradients present in Htâ€‹xsubscriptğ»ğ‘¡ğ‘¥H_{tx} in (3) for the same SW expected in the two designs. Indicative of a lossless property, Xxâ€‹z=Xzâ€‹xsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘¥ğ‘§subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘§ğ‘¥X_{xz}=X_{zx} is observed.

Since launching the output GB using a localized source is of interest, we adopt a localized source in the form of a two-element array around x=0ğ‘¥0x=0. In other words, the +xğ‘¥+x-propagating constant-amplitude SW near x=0ğ‘¥0x=0 is provided by a current probe instead of an input GB. Two elementary radiators separated by a quarter wavelength with a 90Â° phase difference can create a unidirectional radiation patternÂ Balanis (2005). Hence, denoting the attenuation constant of the SW around x=0ğ‘¥0x=0 by Î±csubscriptğ›¼c\alpha_{\text{c}}, we use an impressed electric current source given by

in 0â‰¤yâ‰¤Î»c/40ğ‘¦subscriptğœ†c40\leq y\leq\lambda_{\text{c}}/4 and zero in y>Î»c/4ğ‘¦subscriptğœ†c4y>\lambda_{\text{c}}/4, where Î»c=2â€‹Ï€/kcsubscriptğœ†c2ğœ‹subscriptğ‘˜c\lambda_{\text{c}}=2\pi/k_{\text{c}} is the guided wavelength of the SW. This model represents two strips of vertical electric current of a Î»c/4subscriptğœ†c4\lambda_{\text{c}}/4 height. Their yğ‘¦y-dependence is matched to that of the TM SW for maximum coupling. In simulation results that follow, J0=1â€‹A/msubscriptğ½01A/mJ_{0}=1~{}\text{A/m} has been used.

Snapshots of the zğ‘§z-component of the total electric and magnetic fields are plotted in Fig.Â 6. In Fig.Â 6(a), a GB is launched from x=10â€‹Î»ğ‘¥10ğœ†x=10\lambda at an angle of 30Â° as desired. In the snapshot of Hzsubscriptğ»ğ‘§H_{z} in Fig.Â 6(b), the TM-mode wave is visible only as an evanescent wave bound to the surface. The left inset shows a magnified view near the two-element current source at x=0ğ‘¥0x=0. The two short line segments in black indicate the source positions and their height. A constructive interference between the fields generated by the two strip currents produces a +xğ‘¥+x-propagating SW with a maximum amplitude of 1Â A/m (realized on the surface) as designed. A destructive interference results in negligible excitation of an SW toward the âˆ’xğ‘¥-x-axis direction. The inset on the right shows a portion of the SW-to-PW conversion range. The SW amplitude is gradually reduced with increasing xğ‘¥x due to continuous leakage into space.

VI Conclusion

Arbitrary polarization-preserving beam control using passive, lossless impenetrable metasurfaces has been presented. It is based on a custom SW in an orthogonal polarization designed to propagate along the surface. By finding an optimal spatial envelope for the SW such that there is zero normal component for the Poynting vector everywhere on the surface, a lossless metasurface can convert a PW into an SW, guide the SW unattenuated along the surface, and launch a PW via an SW-to-PW transformation. As specific design examples, a GB translator-reflector, a GB launcher excited by a localized source, and a GB-fed flat focusing lens have been presented. Lossless metasurfaces characterized by a reactance tensor in a plane may be realized using an array of rotated subwavelength resonators printed on a grounded dielectric substrate.

Availability of an orthogonal polarization for SW synthesis simplifies the design process owing to the orthogonality of power flow in the surface normal direction between the PW and SW on the metasurface. The same design approach can be envisioned for polarization-converting transformations between the input and output beams or for using an SW that is co-polarized with the input and output beams. SW synthesis in such a scenario is expected to be challenging due to the complex interference power pattern created by the co-polarized PW and SW components in the system.

At microwave frequencies, a planar array of rotated anisotropic printed conductor patch resonators on a grounded dielectric substrate is a promising configurationÂ FongÂ etÂ al. (2010); MinattiÂ etÂ al. (2012); PatelÂ andÂ Grbic (2013); LeeÂ andÂ Sievenpiper (2016) that allows accurate, low-cost fabrication for realizing the inhomogeneous, tensor surface impedances in this study.
